conversation.speaker: doctor
conversation.text: Good afternoon. What brings you in today?

conversation.speaker: patient
conversation.text: Hi doctor. For the past few weeks, I've been having runny and stuffy nose, itchy and watery eyes, and sneezing a lot. It has been worse when I go outside.

conversation.speaker: doctor
conversation.text: I see. Do you have any known allergies?

conversation.speaker: patient
conversation.text: Well, I've always had hay fever in the spring and fall, but this year it seems to be worse.

conversation.speaker: doctor
conversation.text: Have you noticed any patterns? Are these symptoms worse at any particular time of the day or in a particular location?

conversation.speaker: patient
conversation.text: They seem to be worse in the morning and when I am near plants or flowers.

conversation.speaker: doctor
conversation.text: Have you been using any medications so far?

conversation.speaker: patient
conversation.text: I've been using over-the-counter antihistamines, but they aren't helping much.

conversation.speaker: doctor
conversation.text: Thank you for the information. Let's conduct a physical examination, mainly focusing on your nasal passage and eyes.

conversation.speaker: doctor
conversation.text: Thank you for your patience. Based on your symptoms and the examination, it seems like your allergic rhinitis is acting up. This is consistent with your history of hay fever.

conversation.speaker: patient
conversation.text: Is there anything I can do to help this?

conversation.speaker: doctor
conversation.text: Yes, there are several options. I would recommend a prescription-strength antihistamine, a corticosteroid nasal spray, and allergy eye drops. Also, try to limit your exposure to allergens.

conversation.speaker: doctor
conversation.text: I also recommend that you come in for a follow-up visit in 4 weeks to assess your symptoms. If they're not improving, we might need to consider allergy shots.

conversation.speaker: doctor
conversation.text: Great. Just one more thing, do you get your flu shot every year?

conversation.speaker: doctor
conversation.text: Given your allergies, it would be beneficial for you to get a flu shot. It can help protect you from getting the flu which could potentially worsen your allergic rhinitis.
